text_otziv: The "Generative AI Level 1 Foundation Plan" course is a game-changer! It provides a comprehensive yet easy-to-understand introduction to the world of generative AI. The hands-on exercises and real-world examples make complex concepts digestible. A must-take for anyone looking to dive into this exciting field! Highly recommended.

Really enjoyed the course. Good experience with hands on and excellent explanations. As good as any programming course I've attended. I'm not an expert but my knowledge of python and pt-torch is much better after this course.

UPDATED:
This is course is being update as we speak, the first Implementatio has been migrated to Google Collab using PyTorch and OpenAI's Gym. This is a much welcomed change that better reflect the title of the course, therefore I'm updating my review score as well. As the time of writing, only the first exercise has been updated, but the course managers promised more is to come.
Other than that, there is still a very steep learning curve from Intuition to Implementation, so much that feels like two different courses.
Deep Learning(ANN and CNN) concepts are well explained with images. Great Training and practical coding in Pytorch.
This course is excellent, I love the way all the concepts and the implementation of those concepts have been explained and demonstrated so beautifully. Thanks Kiril and Hadelin!

In general the course is ok, it is really able to get you excited at the very beginning, which is crucial for the students to get the motivation required to start with the great theoretical lectures and go to the implementation sections later on.
However, that exciting sensation and motivation start to decrease specially from the last parts of the Doom module, in particular due to the neverending setup & execution issues.
From a constructive point of view, I'd like to share my thoughts in a bit more ellaborated manner. Hopefully the trainers will read this and maybe agree with one or two points and consider to modify the course a bit to make it even more attractive to new learners

Examples are outdated and they do not update them at all.
Tutors often concentrate on explanation of trivial things (like reading line by line of library importing or explaining for the nth time what is class inheritance), but they skip important stuff (i.e. data manipulation, how python version determines if the code will run or not) and don't show or explain (with examples) what is happening inside the methods (like array and tensor transformations). Besides they do not explain why they use given project architecture - on higher level of abstraction (i.e. how files, classes & methods interconnect) and most importantly, they do not experiment with parameters in the code to show how they influence the behavior of the AI (number of layer in NN, level of rewards, temperature, number of inputs etc.). Whole programming part is just reading code line by line. Very disappointed.

I was very disappointed to find out there were so many prerequisites for this course. "High School Maths" and "Basic Python knowledge" are never enough to take this course. Much more advanced math skills and experiences, as well as some years of hands-on Python and AI experiences, are needed to even keep up with this course. On top of that, you will probably need to spend many hours studying external resources to get a lot out of this course. If you satisfy all these, you might find this course beneficial. Maybe. I wanted to know all the downsides before I purchased this course.

Course is good, easy concepts, but difficult implementations in python.
But what troubled me the most (i'm sure other students felt the same) is the way the QA are answered by Mr Jordan. He is a well mannered, nice man but I don't think teaching / explaining suits him. He is really bad at explaining / answering our questions, often referring us to multiple useless or unrelated links for us to find out ourselves.
Out of all of the QA answered by Jordan, I must say 95% were useless.

The intuitive parts of the course were very good but the coding part by Hadelin lacked depth and was really difficult to grasp and assimilate especially for a novice. The concepts associated with the codes should have been explained in a more extensive and coherent manner.

This is a great training to encompass the recent evolutions of AI.
It explains why AI is powerful today and then illustrate how to apply it with a very powerful framework on examples like a self-driving car prototype or the game "Doom". The examples are easy to understand and you navigate in the programming side step by step. The results of the programmes are discussed so that you can also get a flavour of AI current limitations and its potential of extra evolution. You "just" need afterwards to imagine the rest to extrapolate in real-world situations.
Multiple articles and web sites are refered to deepen the theory and practice.

This course is setup so that the more you know the more you learn. I put a lot of effort into this course and got way more than I expected out of it. I am a big fan of these instructors and I purchased many courses and a book from them.

The theory part was absolutely wonderful, I grasped every concept properly. I didn't like the coding part very much since it felt kind of rushed and also too complicated. Also, the course needs updating since many packages used in the course are outdated, especially for Doom module since it is no more available in the package. Maybe replace it with other game. But overall, I liked the course but I would really like to see it being updated.

The theory parts of the course were great but the coding part was basically non-existent. If you want to get started in the field of deep learning, go learn Tensorflow and take a course on that. This course should only be bought if you want to learn theory.
Requirements for this course is much more than high school maths. It requires python programming knowlege too which they didn't mention in overview.

This course was really useful. It gave me a complete picture about AI theoretically as well as practically. Explanation of the code was really clear and enjoyed each and every details of it. Thanks a ton for giving us, an awesome course on AI. Keep up the good work!

This is an extraordinary course and is exactly what I was looking for, as the instructors not only give a thorough explanation of deep Q-Learning, their model of the Self-Driving car and how they enjoyed it as it learned had me laughing, and the part of the level of the AI playing Doom was fantastic.
I wanted to develop an AI and not just a bot, but one that when I "turn it off" I can then use the laptop on my own, and this course explains that and more!
Highly recommend this course to anyone wanting to learn about Neural networks and anything related to the science of AI and Deep Q-Learning!
It is the best course on the internet for anybody who wants to get started with Artificial Intelligence should get started with this !!
This course is absolute delight. I would also like to see much more maths explained in A3C and SARSA learning in future. I would definitely say its a good course to begin with reinforcement learning
The course was informative and really good especially for a beginner with some programming(OOP) background !
Very positive. I'd like more small opportunities for implementation. Would also like exposure to TensorFlow. Software is out of date

It's a great start in the field of AI.
Simple explanations, useful and practical examples, and definitely a good focus in Python. It is highly advisable to understand more than the basics of Python, so as to be able to adjust the code.
I'd suggest any related course from the same instructors!
The Problem I faced was in installing the software needed to learn the course and the instructions were quite outdated.

Really enjoyed the instructors! They certainly had a passion for what they were teaching and taught it well. What they included in this class was really great, but AI's a big realm, and this barely scratches the surface. For me to jump start faster, I'd like to have seen more the in the following realms:
*Choosing which problems would be best solved by AIs
*Building an AI from scratch - not just following someone else's model
*Specifically stepping through the thought process of the concept,

It started well, I liked the intuition parts, which basically explain the idea. And most of the time the tutors are very enthusiastic which is good. The issue is in trying to replicate the solution(s). To prevent issues you may need to recreate a specific (Python) environment. Using a newer Python environment, frameworks or libraries may get you into trouble and may lead to stranded products. Sometimes it gets a bit long winding, going through every line of code, sometimes without a good explanation of the parameters or API. Not bad in itself, you may need to look up stuff, like how PyTorch works or what the parameters really mean. I missed a kind of schematic overview.

Although the theoretical and practical parts of the course were intriguing, ı had some issues with the installation process of the packages. Since codes were written in prior versions of python newcomers such as me had to downgrade their python version, and ı had no clue how to do that. If the instructors update their codes and packages, this course will be great.

Instructors are very enthusiastic, but lecture material is pretty high level. Does provide a lot of good references to research papers, which can be used to fill in the gaps. Code along explanations are not very detailed and some examples use old code and tools (doom, breakout).

I am a novice in this field but, now I feel a bit confident with AI. For me self-driving car and doom were superb but I faced difficulty with the last application. But now I have a direction to learn and built the last code properly.
Thanks

Its a great course so far. However, there are few technical glitches - blurred screen and freezing of the tutorial at various times.
In all this course incorporates the various component principles of AI, ML and DS.
However, as a Change management Consultant, I recommend some tutorial of practical application in Business, Society, etc.
Thank your for the deep knowledge of AI
Frank

The course is good at educating the user in reinforcement learning and gives good additonal resources to improve your learning in some cases. Although sometimes they miss the mark of explaining some terms (for example experience replay).
But the reason I can not give it more than 2.5 star rating is because of the practical part.
If you are a Windows user like me, you will spend more time trying to fix your code of out-dated libraries and environments. Just to realise the libraries are not realy ment for the Windows operating system. So then you spend more time on installing a virtual machine and still not making it work.
The theory is excellent but in coding, please consider the students who are not familiar with all packages of python and other functions

The theory per se is quite good, so are the teachers.
BE AWARE you will spend a great deal of time getting the dev environment to work instead of watching the lectures.
It is a great learning experience to understand the fundamentals of CNN. The course give some insight of AI.

More Visual Examples would be great while the implementation part. Overall course is good. Although a lot of depreciation issues with PyTorch as it was implemented 3 years back. Would really save some time for the students if the course could be updated with the latest PyTorch version.

O código está completamente desactualizado.
Secção do Doom podia ter mais imagens da explicação teórica enquanto explica o código para perceber melhor o que o código está a fazer e em que parte do algoritmo está.

The theory of the course was really interesting, but the practical side has a lot of issues as the code is for old versions of various libraries or software - so more time is spend debugging than learning. Sadly the course hasn't been updated with a list of URLs and corrections for code just to allow the learning to take place. Its a real shame as if this worked then the course would be 5 stars in both theory and practical.
detailed course with coverage of most of the AI topics. includes annex with details on ANN & CNN which is a added bonus
The course introduces amazingly complex ideas in sensical ways and the coding walkthroughs and explanations are fantastic and easy to follow with just a basic understanding of python
Overall, good place to start with if you have good programming experience. Some of the explanations are unclear for me. Also, most of time times I was struck with errors that I couldn't solve.

Pretty amazing course, just unfortunately after following 70% of the course I could not do anything past part 1 self-driving car cause I'm on windows and support suggest installing VM, which I'll lose a lot of performance and since my laptop is equipt with an SSD there is no luxury of free space for installing a completely new VM and all the required packages again. For me not having the required resources is one thing, but the videos continue as if all is good and compatible with windows as well. I feel like as is, the course should be labeled "Ubuntu/Mac only".
Yeah it was great course, I learnt a lot about the neural networks, great teachers too....there could be more fun added to the slides...…..from the beginning...……

Great video lectures and very easy to understand.
It was above my expectations and I really enjoyed the course.
I learned a lot of things that helped my practical knowledge.
But there were a few problems like:-
1. It takes 10 days for the instructor to solve the queries in the Q/A section and many times the answer provided also does not work.
2. Captions didn't match

It was cool to be able to see an overview of AI and how to actually do the code to make it happen. I wish I had been more versed in Python and in the Pytorch libraries, it was challenging to visualize what data each line of code was actually manipulating.

It's a good course for beginners only to make an idea about AI, but, unfortunately, the code used there cannot be really helpful to generate the expected results, because it's based on older Pytorch / OpenAI Gym versions, which don't work anymore nowadays.

An excellent and challenging course for someone new to Machine Learning. The appendices represent some of best explanations of machine learning concepts that I have seen thus far. The line-by-line explanation of the ML implementation code was outstanding. This course is worthwhile and a real value.

As of 6/26/17: Not bad as an introduction to artificial intelligence - the explanation of what neural networks are and how they work is particularly enlightening. But the course seems incomplete as a full introduction to artificial intelligence, and is brought down by avoidable problems.
A couple of crucial lectures in the intuition section are missing a mount pointer that describes what the lecturer is explaining about. Once the course gets to practical implementation of a self driving car, there is inconsistency and confusion in language and keywords (e.g. dimensions/axes of a Tensor vs. 5 dimensions of the self driving car's input), and not enough visual aid or practical problems given to help students fully understand what is going on. After the car AI is built, the lecturer simply tells the student "there is a problem with the implementation we have, solve it on your own and get back to us." This may not be so bad for people with some prior knowledge of artificial intelligence, but as a course that is advertised as for beginners, it is simply not enough guidance.

I think the A3C model could use more details. Additionally the course wasn't ported to work on windows (although I ported it myself and added directions so it should no longer be a problem) I would appreciate if the course also allowed for working with GPU... the A3C model is written to work on multiple cores and I think it will take me a while to figure out how to make it work on GPU.
Other then that i think this course is best course for reinforcement learning I took so far.

A number of early lessons (self driving car) discuss changes in state, or progress of an agent, with no visual reference, no mouse pointer overlay, just a static image. It's not enjoyable to spend 15 minutes listening to a voice saying 'here' and 'along this wall' without visual reference. Later lessons are better quality

The intuition lectures and the general AI explanation is really good (and steers away from heavy math as I prefer), but I was disappointed to see that the gym environment used in the last two sections to play Doom and Breakout doesn't work properly on Windows. Not only that, but the installation steps at the beginning of the sections are outdated and don't work as expected either. They provide support over the Q&A section, but I think this course needs an update to fix these issues (in that case it would become a 5-star course as far as I'm concerned). Long story short, as it is, I recommend it for anyone looking to get into AI, but don't expect too much out of the practice lessons (at least when testing the code and watching the AI play some games).

Great course which is divided into lectures on Intuition (theories and concepts) with references written by the author-postulants, and implementation with visualizations, and rationales for algorithms and codes. Deep-Q learning was with Self-Driving Car, Deep Convolutional Q-Learning was with AI playing Doom, and state-of-the-art A3C was with AI playing Breakout, with assistance from Adam Paszke, original author of PyTorch.
being a newbie to ai and python, it gave me a real since of the virtually unlimited possibilities of ai and data science, i would recommend this for all new comers to this field..

Door de accenten van de docenten is het voor no-natives lastig te volgen en de ondertiteling werkt daardoor ook niet.
Ook is het materiaal soms verouderd waardoor het soms lastig is om een bepaalde les te volgen / reproduceren.
Het motiveert niet echt om het dan vol te houden. Ook ben ik bezig met mijn "eigen" AI implementatie en daar zou ik graag wat vragen over willen stellen. Onderdelen die je lastig vind, wat verder uit te diepen. De opgegeven extra lesstof is niet voor iedereen zomaar te begrijpen en daardoor is deze cursus achteraf niet de meest verstandig voor mij.

The course was pretty comprehensive and well designed. The structure was excellent. Great overall learning experience. I am a windows user and could not install 2 out of 3 games from open gym. We need better support in that area.
I love this course, I just need to relearn and relearn about the courses. Thank you Kirill, Hadelin and teams!

This is a overall a really good course. I however couldn´t give it a higher rate because one of the main parts of the section that actually draws attention, building an AI to play Doom, is pretty much obsolete for Windows Users.
The code is based on some libraries that have been taken down from the original site, and it´s really nearly mission impossible for Windows Users to get the code working.
Besides this, the content is really good, and you still can follow the code as it´s being explained. The last part of the course get´s really complicated, but I guess that´s to do with the in depth of the course into AI.
Kiril makes the boring sections exciting and Hadelin ensures that the exciting parts of the course become confusing and completely disengaging.

This course has been extremely helpful and explanatory for people who have limited knowledge on Object Oriented Programming. I had issues however with downloading certain packages, but I was able to troubleshoot the importing issues/ missing packages from online sources and the Q&A section at times. It might be my operating system, but over all extremely fun!

2nd and 3rd set of code and its configuration not for windows even though they claim to provide install instructions for windows. Also did not provide info on versions of libraries to use. Default installs are installing newer versions that are not compatible. Have to do a lot of digging around the Q&A then sometimes find where they said use a specific version. But, the information is piecemeal, so very frustrating.
Was an Awesome course...The simplicity with which complex topics were explained and taken through is amazing. Thank you team for putting up this brilliant tutorial.
I am new to Artificial intelligence I am pretty excited to learn from scratch, of course I have completed a course on Machine Learning A-Z using Python and R, now completed this course on AI.

A fantastic course!!! Covered everything I needed to go from knowing little about AI, through the theory, into building AI programs in Anaconda to solve games and real world puzzles. Thanks to Kirill, Hadelin and team for their excellent tutelage.

Only minimal insight regarding torch was provided; Some structural and conceptual framework would have been better. Although I spent much time trying to get outdated environments to work, there seemed to always be some roadblock (even when trying both Linux and Windows Anaconda versions with current and prior python versions). Plan of attack only specified python environment but failed to mention items like gym[atari] or ppaequette-doom. Having an accurate and complete setup plan would have helped immensely; if versions were specified, I could have established an Anaconda environment that worked. Finally, it is very annoying that the answer in the Q&A seems to always be "downgrade" rather than update the code; further evidence the material is overly outdated.

This course went to amazing depth and was easy to understand, due to the excellent explanations from the instructors. They are passionate about the subject matter and it showed with the course. I highly recommend it.

Everything is going well until the course encountered to pytorch & tensorflow.
I'm already familiar with python but not have prior knowledge about pytorch, the programming part could be better if it would've been given with proper explaination that how to use those functions, modules and all. Also i was facing too many errors while executing the map.py , rather than giving the solution in written , better if given a separate video to resolve those error or provided an updated files to access after removing all the errors.
Apart from it, the remaining parts are quite wonderful, got a lot about Al and Deep Q learning in an affordable price. Thanking you
Excellent videos and great explanation I have learned many things about AI and also the games also I have enjoyed very much ones again thank you????
Good introduction and thorough code, but would have liked more details explained, specifically the math involved. Also would have liked a better explanation on back propagation.

OUTDATED! Do not buy it anymore!
Keep this in mind, this course is outdated and you can't experiment at all. You literally invest more time in a VM and errors to make it work. You can find all of resources on GitHub (and I'm mad for this).
I think this course was a thing back then, but now is just a HUGE pain to work it out.
I don't even know why Udemy is still recommending it.
The only good stuff in here is the theoretical stuff.

Have been fascinated by AI for decades. Looking to get more info on the subject.
Like past courses with these trainers. However, less than impressed with this course. The code is outdated and fails for multiple reasons. Also the Gym modules are problematic. The version listed for Conda is available Mac only, not using a Mac.
Though research and checking forums, have been able to resolve several issues. With partial success. For Gym, the are multiple forks available, finding the version is doable. However, takes time.

2019-10-28 Update -> Dropping the rating on this course from 5 stars to 4. There's only 3 codes reviewed in the entire course and 2 of them use the Gym environment that most reviewers can't get to work. I'm spending as much time researching the Gym issue as I am watching the courses (like right now). I've tried on Mac and Windows, I've tried google searches, I've tried searching Udemy reviews. Nothing is working.
Mid-October 2019 -> This course is great, just like all of the courses by SuperDataScience team. They do a great job explaining the theory, projects, programming language and everything else. I really liked how they started at a high level explaining the concepts like the bellman equation, markov decision process, temporal difference, etc. and then get into the projects. Understanding the theory helps a lot when you get to the coding projects. This stuff is complicated, and they do a really good job explaining it all.

The theory is excellent, and the course is probably worth it just for that.
Unfortunately, while the first example is great, and I got it working with relatively no trouble, the latter examples suffer from an over-emphasis on Python syntax basics, whilst ignoring significant aspects of how/why the PyTorch libraries (the AI bits!) are being used. This wouldn't be so bad, but it's difficult (I eventually gave up) to replicate the 2nd/3rd exercises yourself in 2020 as best as I can tell, since various things have moved on or are no longer available. A good course overall, but seems you'll need to go investigate PyTorch yourself to really understand the latter parts.

Prinzipiell bin ich zufrieden mit dem Kurs. Man bekommt die Theorie hinter Neuronalen Netzen vermittelt und diese wird an mehreren Code-Beispielen veranschaulicht. Leider ist das Ganze wie eine Berieselung und man wird selbst nicht aktiv bei der ganzen Sache. Ich denke durch die Abgabe von Übungen (automatisierte Überprüfung -> Siehe Coursera 'Machine Learning') hat man einen deutlich höheren Lernerfolg. Nichts des der Trotz ist der Inhalt sehr interessant und ich habe einiges im Bereich Reinforcement Learning hinzugelernt.

This course was very well done. I appreciated the style where you first learn the content, then code it. The applications were great! It was cool to see an AI learn to drive a car, play doom and play an atari game. I now understand the basics of AI. The professors give you tons of extra resources to do more learning and research. I will say that a pytorch tutorial would be incredibly helpful with this course. I could grasp what was going on with pytorch for the most part, but I think knowing pytorch better would be very helpful and recommended for anyone who goes through this course. I will also say that it was difficult for me to tell which parts of code corresponded to which parts of the formulas that make up AI structure. But if I understood pytorch better and re-watched some things, I bet that would become more clear. Overall, excellent job from these guys!

I like the course but there are two issues that should be addressed:
1. finding the way of installing the environments on different platforms and keeping them updated for the students,
2. reducing the gap between the theory and the examples.

The amount of research papers mentioned and examples of AI working is amazing! Other courses go into the theory only, no examples that what they're teaching can be carried out. I also liked that it wasn't just one person teaching the course; you'd hear Kirill for a while and then Hadelin. Five stars for an exceptional course!

The course is amazing!!! It has content that is amazing and great. I am really new in Artificial Intelligence and yet through the course I was able to grasp as much as I could. I am very excited to be on this adventure in the space of AI, things are very interesting. I look forward to learn many other interesting AIs. Great course, thank you . Keep it up.
A great overview and examples of what AI can be used for - and what it can do. A lot of external references are given to expand your learning opportunities.

It began quite well and covered the basics but was let down by having terrible instructions for getting the python packages installed and working. After a few hours trying to get the environment working in windows and then in a linux virtual environment, I finally gave up and was unable to even begin on the doom project.

I have enjoyed the AI from A to Z.
Now I have a major idea about how AI works.
I most enjoyed the self driving car game, it is really amazing.
Doom is kind of old, but impressive too.
Breakout is also outstanding.
I would like to point out for something: AI is meant for engineers/smart people that understand very quickly. Please go straight to the point while explaining things.

It is good course where actual impact and need of AI is well explained.
It describes state-of-the-art research reports and critical evaluations of applications, techniques and algorithms in artificial intelligence, cognitive science and related disciplines.
It serves as a forum for the work of researchers and application developers from these fields.
I like it.

This is actually an excellent course, only based on the contents, Techniques and the algorithms that are covered in the tutorials. The topics they have covered are so great and its very important to those in the field of AI.
But its not for the beginners, may be not for the intermediates too, may be not but definitely not for the beginners.
I came here after completing my machine learning and deep learning courses and they were so good. This course lacks in covering the basics unlike the former courses i studied from the same instructors team. they need to cover more basics and they definitely need to update the course. The most important and basic packages were not available today or available only for a particular OS or Python version or at least they have to provide an alternate solution. simply using the Virtual Machine with installed packages doesn't solve the problem. I'm totally not at all satisfied with this course like i was with my former courses.
The course was very interesting, but most of the programming tasks were outdated and could not do them. It would be good if the course/code is updated every year!!

I found the info. is just right till yet. Further i am expecting to learn things in the best way possible since i don't have any maths background neither basic knowledge of python, i don't know how useful it'll turn out for me.

It is good as other courses from superdatascience, intuition parts are great but I think code examples are not that good. Instead of having fancy stuff like Breakout, Doom which requires to learn 3rd party libraries there could be more basic but more explanatory vanilla examples. Overall it is good and beneficial.

Great course that walks through intuitive concepts, to mathematical foundation and to detailed line by line coding. Obviously the courseware was built in 2017, some of the code/libraries are out of date now, but still works with some hacks. What a wonderful treat!

The course could have been a 5 star if:
Introduction to python (or at least saying that you need a nice understanding of this language)
Giving code challenges, because it is not possible for a newbie (even a good dev) to code by himself those AIs without knowing the libraries.
Overall it is a nice introduction to AI, but you will need to put way more work by yourself without a guide.

Constantly repetition of some concepts without summarizing the general ideas, lets whom is listenning get a little tired, particulary in lecture 20, section 5, the same screen for the entire video. But, the course is very interesting and easy to get along and acquire the concepts of deep learning and artificial neural networks.

The theory and information is extremely useful, however, the only problem with this course is how fast technology upgrades, one year to humans can be considered decades to computer programs. Most of the Downloadable Materials they have stored are outdated and most of the solutions they supposedly present aren't useful anymore nor do they provide quick, useful information. You need computer and programming experience to navigate and solve those problems which can become time-consuming. If you have intermediate knowledge prior to this course then it's okay. If you are an absolute beginner, it will be a monstrous challenge.

A wonderful course on AI that had some fun parts too as well as the technical side. I would definitely recommend Linux or OS X for the programs though. Nice improvement over some earlier courses because of the addition of references.

The course is broken into pairs of theory and practical. The theory sections are pretty decent and explain the concepts very nicely. But in the code sections, the instructors are just looking at a piece of paper and writing it on screen. They talk about what they are doing, but there is little to no explanation on WHY they are doing things. I would not recommend this to a complete beginner.

This was totally new for me but it was really very exciting, basically the self driven car, it is awesome,
Thank you so much for such a wonderful session.

Excellent tutorial to learn about Artificial Intelligence! All the basics AI concepts are clearly explained: theoretical and practical !
Well done and thank you so much for this great job !

After taking the Deep-Learning course from you guys I had quite high expectations from this course. Long story short I am disappointed. The instruction of the course sais that all you need is some high-school math, but that is not true. For someone who hasn't seen pytorch in their life, the course is really hard to get into. There has to be a dedicated section where you explain the very basics of pytorch by simply building an ANN. Also in parts 2 and 3(DOOM, A3C) the installation steps do not work. In order to get some packages working it is required to downgrade them(which is not specified) and whatever I tried I could not get DOOM working on Ubuntu. You should have put dedicated videos on how to install OpenAI on anaconda environments since this is the "IDE" that you are using on this course.
Awesome! Awesome! Very good presentation of course and references used in this. This course gave knowledge to proceed further with AI and explore and implement more to build an AI.

Not a full five due to non notice of need for Ubuntu or VM with Ubuntu. Hope you find this a constructive criticism, good explanation of AI concepts, but a bit too repetitive, and could use a more thorough explanation of the pytorch tool

Great course which gives perspective. Difficult in the good sense of the word, so I will look through it more times to completely understand all concepts. The only thing is that I could not run all exercises without errors, because some packages are not actual in December 2018. I hope that instructors will fix it. But despite it, I anyway recommend it to those who want to take challenging courses.
course is fine but in 2nd section (CNN) they did not mention that you need ubuntu or macos in order to see the results of project. I think they have to mention that at the mainpage of course
What is really helpful and great with this course is the course structure, starting from basics till mastering professional level of competencies.
One of the best courses and instructors I have ever had. Thanks a lot Professor Hadellin and proffesor Kirill

The introduction itself was at par the expectations and the excitement has kicked in already. Hoping to learn with the instructors. All i can say is that I am very very optimistic about the outcome after I go through the entire course.
[update]
Finally completed the course and it was an amazing journey. This was a lifetime experience and was able to learn many things. The only thing is wider topics are not covered like in practical and real world sense, meaning current applications, their implementation etc, which could have really helped to know the in and out of the current AI implementations. But to the best of the learning, the quick takeaway were the references to articles, papers and books for further reading. Overall, a time well spent. Kudos to the instructors and Udemy.

The intuition lectures were really good, but I had a lot of trouble keeping up with the practical sessions. I think it's better to mention in advance that some prerequisite knowledge of pytorch and object-oriented programmed is highly recommended. Otherwise, it is just a code along project without really understanding what is happening.

A very good course, providing a practical introduction and implementation into 3 neural networks. Pretty good explanations. Though its best to take this after doing ML and DL A-Z courses.
Not-5 stars since some of the codes require a python environment with quite old libraries, some of which are not well maintained by their respective authors. But that being said the team is in the process of replacing and improving those codes to google-colab.
Edit 1 : The team has already added a google-colab version for the doom practical section. So with people who originally had to use the VMs prebuilt with Doom no longer need to use them.

Don't waste your time. The whole second half of the course doesn't even work which is the part I wanted to see the most (Doom). Asked for help several times and never got a satisfactory answer or solution. So disappointed!

The Doom and Breakout parts of the course are outdated and you need to setup an Ubuntu VM and do a lot of fiddling in order to get it to work. Besides that the implementation material often shows you what to do, but lacks depth in why you should do it that way. It's good for improving your AI intuition, however I feel it lacks depth.

through out the lecture so far is really going great, but during the practical part of the lecture, sometime the lecturer couldn't really put the word into a simple way so i could understand it better, i always have to stop and go to the Q&A or google to ask some questions . despite of that so far is really exciting and fun

Admittedly, it is one of the most difficult online course that I have taken so far but the instructors really took their time to explain the concepts well. The materials are very good and the outline clearly shows the depth of the discussion. I appreciate that the Annexes were separated out. Thanks to the conscientious instructors. Well done!

This was the first AI course I took. It was a great experience for me although some of the installations for the state-of-the-art ai technology was moving ahead making it difficult to install and get the same results. However, this is a great course.

Some content is outdated. The course uses a very old version of pytorch. Doom is no longer available on openAI gym. Some other places in the coding exercices need to be updated (instead of asking to install outdated packages). But otherwise the course is quite interesting. Some lectures are way to long for very few new information, but overall impression is good. It's definitely not an advanced course though. There is a gap between the level of the explanations and the recommended literature suggested in the course.
thanks to you all for your wonderful contribution to inculcate the AI knowledge it to students like me. It was awesome.

A very fun course. I really enjoyed seeing how to actually use a neural network rather than just create one. I would recommend taking their Deep Learning course first because that will give an in depth explanation of neural networks, and then this AI course provides the knowledge about taking that neural network's output and using it as a brain to make decisions that something else can actuate. Neural Networks are amazing but seeing their results manifesting in a game rather than just numbers on the screen definitely takes it to the next level. While they didn't go into the maths behind it in much detail, instead referencing papers, I actually prefer that because there's so much detail already published in papers. There's no point just reproducing it. Instead this course distills that detail into intuition explanations and working programs that you can use today, so it's a great bridge between learning it as a beginner and following up by reading the papers yourself. Great job again guys.

1. Complete beginner to expert AI skills – Learn to code self-improving AI for a range of purposes. In fact, we code together with you. Every tutorial starts with a blank page and we write up the code from scratch. This way you can follow along and understand exactly how the code comes together and what each line means.
2. Code templates – Plus, you’ll get downloadable Python code templates for every AI you build in the course. This makes building truly unique AI as simple as changing a few lines of code. If you unleash your imagination, the potential is unlimited.
3. Intuition Tutorials – Where most courses simply bombard you with dense theory and set you on your way, we believe in developing a deep understanding for not only what you’re doing, but why you’re doing it. That’s why we don’t throw complex mathematics at you, but focus on building up your intuition in coding AI making for infinitely better results down the line.

I quite enjoyed the theory portion of the course where I felt like I learned a lot about artificial intelligence. However, the application portion of the course, which I was most looking forward to, has been nothing more than a let down. Their installation guide for the software required is horrible. It took me six hours to find a way for the self driving car's code to be functional, until I finally created a workaround to this problem by using a virtual machine with Ubuntu 18.04. The instructor responsible for the application portion of the course, has a difficult accent to understand, and gives long complicated explanations for what each line of code is doing, but you still do not understand what it is that it does despite listening to it several times. Through the application process, it doesn't feel like you are going through the "development" of the code. You are basically just copying the lines that he writes on the screen, without understanding what is going on, which is different than other courses I have taken where I can "see" how the application should be designed so that the goal is reached. In the self driving car section for example, you write the entire AI code without once testing it throughout the development process. In my opinion, this is not a good approach as we cannot see how the lines of code we are writing are actually going to affect its behavior. The biggest annoyance is that there feels like there is a disconnect between the theory portion and the application portion, as I was hoping that we would write our own neural network and AI from scratch, whereas you actually use PyTorch to do a lot of the "behind the scenes". I would only recommend this course for the AI theory, as there are some excellent explanations within those lectures about what is being discussed, and the referrals for supplementary material are also phenomenal.

While the theoretical components of this course were very simplified and covered from a very high level basic components of machine learning - the practical components of this course offered little or no knowledge towards utilising anything you've learned.
Hours are wasted watching code be typed out using vague variable names followed by poor explanations of what the code is actually doing - or even what the options available to customise are.
In the several hours of course content around writing Python code almost nothing is gained from watching it all be written out line-by-line, with approximately only several minutes in the several hours being useful when it is explained what very particular functionality does (with the rest being vaguely skimmed over). All that is required for these entire sections is 1 or 2 lectures going through the full written out examples explaining which parts of the code are relevant to the machine learning components, as the rest is gibberish unless you already understand python as well as the relevant libraries.

My rating is really the average of a 3 for the conceptual part - and read on, because this is a very subjective "for me" rating - and a 5 for the coding components. I think my experience is a bit above the intended level from the conceptual understanding side of the explanations, so some of the points seem a little belabored. But that's not really the fault of the course, just me trying to learn to interpret the course description and connect it to the likely level of presentation difficulty. And I think the thoroughness of explanations is probably more of a benefit to a large number of people who take this course. So my rating shouldn't be a general rating (they do explain things very well), just a testament to how the level of teaching meshes with my level of understanding, so I wish that part of the course would have moved along more quickly. On the other hand, I'm not as good at the actual coding, so I find the way they explain the code line by line amazing for my ability to understand and also be able to reproduce and build code of my own using the concepts that are covered. So far, I've gotten a lot out of this course (I'm still only half way through) and would definitely recommend it! Oh, I also really like how they provide additional reading references that they've found relevant and useful. There's too much literature out there for me to want to vet myself.
